Definition: Break down the given comment into Identity-attack and Non-identity-attack. Identity attack refers to anything offensive, rude about one’s identity.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: Silly Americans, laws are for poor people.
Positive Examples.explanation: This comment contains identity attacks on Americans.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: More annoying drivel from plagiarist Wente.
Positive Examples.explanation: This comment is unrelated and does not contain identity attacks.

Negative Examples.explanation: This comment should be non-identity-attack because it is not disrespectful to any groups.

Negative Examples.input: Comment: The Canadian gang of fools at the table.
Negative Examples.explanation: This should be identity-attack because the comment contains identity attacks on Canadian.

Comment: "He said dogma guided the country's founders, who believed citizens should practice "their faith freely and without apology."

No to the first part of that but yes to the second. The founding fathers were mostly Enlightenment Age rationalists who were deists at best. To say that religious dogma guided them borders on untruth. In shaping a new republic they were guided by the fundamental principle of the separation between church and state, i.e. that no church would ever dictate law.

As for the (faux) outrage at Senator Feinstein's questions, since when have legitimate questions about anything having to do with a candidate's belief system been out of bounds when judicial nominees undergo questioning? Things have certainly changed since the days when JFK went out of his way to assure WASP voters that Rome would never guide his actions as president and U.S. bishops were as quiet as a bunch of church mice in their eager determination to get a Catholic in the White House.

Comment: Cal's biggest quakes are 100 times less powerful than the one we are going to have. Also, they are mostly in areas that have many access points. 

We're in a unique situation out here on the Oly Pen, particularly if Seattle is essentially destroyed (old buildings and lots of them), Portland possibly as well, and require more help than the entire country can provide. 

We won't be forgotten, but we're a couple of drops in a bathtub of trouble. Rural self-reliance and preparation is the name of the game. It's hard to get food and fuel out here after every bridge has been taken out. 

Grocery store stock won't last for more than a few hours after the big one, assuming its not already buried.  Fuel will last a bit longer given there won't be any power to pump it.

How many years do you think it will take to rebuild all our bridges when everyone is also trying to rebuild Seattle and Portland? Look how long it takes to build one bridge now. Imagine with hundreds of bridges down in the PNW.

Comment: First, you're flat-out wrong.  The Church has NEVER held that conscience is the determinant of the moral content of an action nor that conscience can turn an objectively evil act into something objectively good.  Good heavens, man.  
Second, yes, the Church acknowledges the critical role of conscience but has always qualified the concept by placing it within the framework of a conscience correctly formed and informed. 
Third, if one were to assign primacy to conscience, then there is literally no action, however monstrous or evil, that could not end up being somehow rationalized.  This is contrary to logic, reason, and, yes, Church teaching.  
Finally, I'll repeat the question I posed elsewhere in this thread: if a Nazi guard at Auschwitz participates in mass murder, can he later, as a matter of moral reasoning, justify the crime as a product of his (convoluted) "conscience"?  
I won't hold my breath waiting for an answer.

Comment: Capacity factor is his first fallacy.
Second is that hydrocarbon fuels won't change in price because they are not a technology.  Well here's news, an electron isn't technology either.  Fracking as a technology example, brought wholesale worldwide change to price of hydrocarbons.  
The third is his simplistic view of resources without any concept of economics.  Highlighting windy, wavy or sunny regions is far different from economically harnessing that energy for commercial use.
Fourth, by 2022, for solar and wind to be competitive industrially, let's factor in the storage cost too.  Right now they're incomplete technologies.  This is why cargo ships don't use sails.  So by 2022, on a scale of "useful electrons to a consumer at any point in time" which should be the real measuring stick, they are still not economic.
Lastly, the only private sector investment being made is with subsidy.

Comment: Read my other posts, you may learn something. Only space has kept me from being more detailed. When I ran malware after penetrating my target I'd take everything I wanted including passwords. I'd uninstall the trojan leaving no tracks and then log in as a legitimate user using an IP from the same country so as not to trip any alarms from the administrator. If I was to do something seriously criminal I'd go to another city or country and even if my work could be traced back to a particular location it wouldn't matter. If we assume that the IP location is correct then a Russian ran the inferior, obsolete Ukrainian software that guaranteed detection. Consider that they could have downloaded Chinese malware, since they don't have the skills and resources to create their own software, :)  and then made sure that forensic analysis showed a Chinese origin, perhaps run it from Hong Kong to be safe. We can accuse the Russians of many things and be right but incompetence isn't one of them.

Comment: Love the man's hit recordings, starting with Gentle On My Mind. The documentary on his mental decline is both painful and poignant.  My favourite Campbell hit: Galveston.  That voice!  But much more.  According to the song's writer Jim Webb, Campbell did more than just sing the lyrics.  Said Webb a few years ago: "Glen was very, very good at commercializing my songs. He could come up with great intros and great solos, great breaks, and he wrote perfect strings..."  Campbell may have had a hand in the outstanding musical arrangement of this particular hit. After Campbell stops singing the orchestra--and that great guitar--go on for at least another 30 seconds. The hit is regarded as an anti-war protest song, but Webb insisted it was just the story of man who just wanted to go back home. The "I still hear your sea waves crashing" lyrics were changed. Originally, the verse was:

"Wonder if she could forget me
"I'd go home if they would let me
"Put down this gun
"And go to Galveston."

Comment: Jared those studies find that people with schizophrenia use cannabis, then it gets reported as "cannabis causes schizophrenia". This is the easiest one to debunk actually with logic and stats.  Around the world, about 1 percent of the population is affected by schizophrenia.  So in the last couple of decades cannabis use in the UK has more than doubled, why didn't the schizophrenia diagnosis increase? Why is there no uptick in schizophrenia in Holland, Spain, Uruguay or any of the states in the US with cannabis legalisation?  Cannabis can uncap schizophrenia if you already have it, but haven't been diagnosed.  That's as far as it goes.  Have you considered that people suffering from schizophrenia maybe use cannabis for symptom relief?  Correlation isn't causation my friend.  We need to look much closer at these studies punted by governments bud.  I really don't want to fight, I just want you to look at things from both sides.  You soon see which side has the most to hide and lie about.

Comment: It's an idea, but I also have to put it up against the idea of ignoring people--which I have some objection to since I've been in some communication with Pan for a long time already. I have been in several unpleasant situations where people found ignoring other people was acceptable while I found it ugly, like shunning. I tend to live in hope that there must surely be ways of communicating with anyone; that is foolishness, I know, but I will likely die trying because I value attending to others a lot. It does, also, allow other people to carry on conversations at times while I distract the distractor. I've also walked away from a few lately.


I also don't always like letting comments stand unanswered when a response--while irritating to some--also lets the infrequent reader know that there is likely to be a response to the gibberish some people post. I am currently settled on the solution that a couple of people have mentioned, which is to give a few tries before calling it good.

Comment: I also disagree with Mr. Parker's first comment, but do you actually know what a strawman is? 

A strawman is when someone argues over issue A, and then someone else responds ignoring issue A and introducing issue B, which has nothing to do with issue A (or in this case, try to throw it in at the end randomly). It's a logical fallacy for obvious reasons. 

While I disagree with Mr. Parker's original comment, he is right that the response is a strawman.

Comment: What you say is important.  There is a strain of historical revisionism that rears its ugly head from time to time, and in that telling, the Confederacy was not a rebellion but a revolution, and the "cause" of the War was not the preservation of slavery but the preservation of states' rights.  The first is an attempt to cast secession as a legal act; it wasn't.  The second is an attempt to sanitize a cause which was radically illegitimate: slavery.  The Confederacy is sometimes romanticized as the "Lost Cause"; we need to remember that what was "lost" was the right to buy and sell human beings; and we need to remember the terrible cost in human terms.

Comment: You're misinformed. 

1. "Freedom of expression" includes freedom of speech as well as other kinds of expression. So does the American "freedom of speech" too, for that matter.

2. Governments do not prosecute in human rights tribunals; such tribunals are forums for disputes between two private parties.

The strict test for what constitutes "hate speech" is the same in human rights tribunals as it is in criminal law proceedings under the Criminal Code.

Comment: Larry, I'm not so sure that the democrat party has moved left since the 60's and 70's.  The Blue Dogs you referred to didn't get bumped off by more liberal dems in the primaries.  They got beat by republicans.  Moderate repubs got knocked off by their own party.  Big diff.

But the repub party has swung hard right in recent decades.  Ronald Reagan was considered a far right candidate in his day, but today he wouldn't come close to the nomination.  Look at his record:

He raised taxes 11 times, including on the rich; increased government size and spending; signed immigration reform legislation including a path to citizenship; advocated the Brady gun control law; agreed to a treaty on climate; signed a treaty to reduce nuclear arms with the Soviet Union; and took many other positions that would not pass muster with the right today. Back when he was governor of California, he even supported abortion.

Comment: No, the opposite is true.  If a law appears to be constitutional in its terms, but the application of the law creates an result that is unconstitutional, it is invalid.  The intention of the Charter or of the American constitution is always paramount.  In this case, it was held that the result was unconstitutional.  We will see how other courts react, but they will also have to consider effect over words.

Comment: Now, a presidential candidate could lose while winning 78%+ of the popular vote and 39 states.

In 2012, under the current state-by-state winner-take-all system (not mentioned in the U.S. Constitution, but later enacted by 48 states), voters in just 60 counties and DC could have elected the president in 2012 – even though they represented just 26.3% of voters

In 2000, 537 popular votes in Florida determined that the candidate who had 537,179 less national popular votes would win.

Less than 80,000 votes in 3 states determined the 2016 election, where there was a lead of over 2,8oo,ooo  popular votes nationwide.

Since World War II, a shift of a few thousand votes in 1, 2, or 3 states would have elected a 2nd-place candidate in 6 of the 18 presidential elections

With the end of the primaries the political relevance of 70% of all Americans was finished for the 2016 presidential election.

Comment: It is certainly possible to question the wisdom of Merkel's recent refugee policies, and many thoughtful people have done that. Allowing huge numbers of refugees into Germany in a very short period of time can cause a variety of rather predictable short and long term problems. In addition to causing problems for the local population, this also creates problems for other European countries which had nothing to do with these policies, and encourages more and more refugees to come, from more and more countries. This, in turn, leads to social unrest, and may actually encourage more refugees to risk their lives by attempting unsafe passage to Europe. So, actually, Merkel's reckless and poorly thought out policies can have a negative impact on many people in several countries for years to come and are not above criticism. I actually find it refreshing that Trump actually says what he thinks on these major issues, rather than hiding his thoughts behind meaningless "diplomatic" language.

Comment: Body counts are usually discounted because they are lies, hopes or exaggerations.  In sniping this is compounded because there is money to be made from being a famous sniper- books, teaching. movies. 

To put this story in perspective. The people who compete in very long range shooting normally(under very good conditions) stop getting hits at around 2000 yards.  At very long ranges the bullet is plummeting downward as well as drifting with whatever wind is present- in this case for 10 seconds and an extra 1500 meters to travel all the while losing velocity and falling at an ever steeper angle. The holdover to account for this would be at least a football field and perhaps closer to two.  Since "one shot one kill" clearly isn't possible at 3500 m how many rounds did he fire to figure out where to aim? Remember there was a battle going on so presumably there was a lot of dust etc. How did he see where his first shot hit in order to correct for the next?  It could have hit 100m away.

Comment: The article states that "in Alaska, their rate of re-arrest for sex crimes after four years is only 3 percent, according to Department of Corrections data."

This is not the complete picture.  First, it omits re-arrests for other, non-sex crime offenses.  More importantly, recidivism rates are underestimated for several reasons, including the fact that basing recidivism rates upon "official criminal justice system data obviously omit offenses that are not cleared through an arrest or those that are never reported to the police."

http://www.csom.org/pubs/recidsexof.html

"This distinction is critical in the measurement of recidivism of sex offenders. For a variety of reasons, sexual assault is a vastly underreported crime. The National Crime Victimization Surveys (Bureau of Justice Statistics) conducted in 1994, 1995, and 1998 indicate that only 32 percent (one out of three) of sexual assaults against persons 12 or older are reported to law enforcement."

Comment: The Supreme Court of Canada has certainly made a big mess.

What they did was markedly foolish. They chose to put into motion a set of events that would set criminals free, to the detriment of everyday citizens, if the other arms of government did not meet the strict timeline the Judges imposed.

In other words, they made the egregious error of setting up a mechanism that would ultimately make everyday citizens pay the price for government failure to meet their imposed and tight deadlines.

What a mess. And what a poorly developed ruling from the bench.

In future, when the judicial tail decides to wag the national dog, the tail would do well to set up the needed penalties and reprimands for the individual politicians who fail to meet the judges' strict timelines. That way the politicians, the objects of the court's ire, will bear the brunt of failing the judicial directive, instead of having everyday citizens pay the (too high) price.

Comment: A gun is only an option if you spot the bear from a distance and have the time to get a good shot. IN most other circumstances you will not have the time to get off a good shot or one that stops a bear. Bear spray is your best bet up close. All you have to do is aim it at the bear's face and spray. Once in its eyes and mouth, no matter how large the bear is, it's going to have serious trouble breathing or seeing, period. Always have your bear spray ready, with the safety removed, and easy enough to grab within seconds.

Above all and I've seen it a million times on the trails. NEVER WEAR EARBUDS/HEADPHONES WHILE HIKING. It's the worst things you can do in the woods.

I've had hundreds of bear encounters in the world and I've also been charged twice by brown bears. Luckily I've never had to use a gun or spray.

Comment: I get what you're saying, but many times it takes addicts and homeless years to hit rock bottom or at least a point when they are ready to make a true commitment to get better. But instead of us trying to decide who deserves help more, I think we should see which homeless will accept help and dedicate resources to them.  You can't force addiction counseling on someone that has no intention to quitting or to change their lives and expect it work.  If they have been homeless for 20 years or 20 months I don't really care, as long as they are making an effort to stay off the streets and out of hospitals, jail and detox.  To me it's about helping the people wanting to get help, which is where I think the City will get the most out of it's money.

Comment: What about those who had citizenship stripped but did not lie, commit fraud, criminal acts including terrorism?    My father came as a Home Child from Scotland, worked hard on farms for Canada then went back and served throughout WWII with the Royal Canadian Artillery,   discharged back here in late 1945.  Our mother was his War Bride, who brought us to join Dad in 1946.  We did nothing other than work, farm, serve country (my brother in the Navy) for the next 58 years when, with no notice or hearing, it was stripped.  
I do not agree,  I think we had a right to Notice, Hearing and a way to appeal that revocation.   Citizenship is not just a frill,  a privilege that can be taken on the whim of some politician, bureaucrat or nameless employee to whom the task is delegated.    Sorry,  we could not help being born in WWII Britain, but I still think we should have that citizenship back.

Comment: Ticket sales never cover more than about one-third of opera company costs, here or anywhere else. The rest of the revenue comes in the form of donations plus a few grants now and then. And donors never represent more than a small fraction of the community. Most of the people who attend operas in Eugene donate very little, if anything, beyond the price of their tickets. The fact is, a small number of donors who really love opera are carrying the ball for the rest of the community. The real question is whether they will continue to support opera here. Opera is one of the performing arts that attracts educated people to relocate to Eugene, and that makes it easier to attract employers and grow the economy. Whether you like opera or not, Eugene will be the poorer if Eugene Opera fails to recover.

Comment: It isn't a "narrow" decision at all, because it establishes that wearing a veil is a legitimate religious right to practitioners, and that it must be balanced against one of the most important rights in the whole legal system, the right to a fair trial.  That is a far, far tougher bar for any veil-related religious claim than this ban, which does not involve individual rights balancing at all, and is instead about religious discrimination by the state against one religious subset.

You keep bringing up that Belgian decision, but continental European law on matters like this of a completely different legal tradition and far less concerned with the rights of the individual than Commonwealth legal traditions have been.  It's not something the courts will put much mind to, compared to its own well-developed body of case law on this subject.  "R. v. N.S." effectively settled how the courts were going to treat niqab cases going forward.

Comment: Simple arithmetic coupled with a lack of understanding of basic statistical concepts is to blame for much of the increase in CEO pay. I recently received the annual information package from a major corporation that was searching for a new CEO, which said that the CEO's compensation was set at the 75th percentile of the pay distribution of CEOs of other comparable companies. The 50th percentile is, by definition, average. If every corporation tries to pay its CEO more than average, the average will rise.

I would suggest that compensation committees should start looking at the 25th percentile; if that practice becomes widespread, it will change the upward pressure on CEO pay to downward pressure.

Comment: Wouldn't a better solution be to train people while they work so that they keep up with labour market trends instead of following up after the fact with job training to re-train them? Tying it to unemployment insurance programs is bound to limit it's effectiveness.

And don't we already have skills training? We call them colleges and universities. Maybe the government should invest in making these institutions provide real-world opportunities for students so that they get exposed to the kinds of skills businesses seek. Better yet, employ a polytechnic system where students have to work on projects directly related to an actual business. Gaining knowledge and applying that knowledge will go way further than hoping that someone will take up a new skill after working for 30+ years.

Comment: "... Indigenous entrepreneurs can fuel Canadian economic growth.."
.
.
Nice thought. Take a look at "Northern Ontario Business", and there are plenty of articles on Indigenous businesses.  However, the vast majority are not "out-bound", but "in-bound", which naturally limits them. They almost invariably involve the sub-contracting of a service that either was already provided (for say a mining company to look "inclusive"), or was being delivered by a government agency - like flying in fresh foods to fly-in communities...
.
Short answer, a mine going from having its; own catering staff to sub-contracting the kitchen, janitorial, or laundry staff to the local natives, does foster some level of independence, but I have yet to see a national (or even regional) business built from it.

Comment: Eviction is a tough deal for everyone. It's why we have high standards for our renters. We charge less than we can and are timely fixing problems. We require first, last and a damage deposit. Some people understandably find this too much but it ensures that our renters can handle the rent.  

This paints landlords as bad guys, which is true only sometimes.  We had renters who were late, didn't have money for late fees,  just a bit short, etc.  The rent should have covered most of the mortgage, which we had to pay not matter what. No one wants to protect landlords so they have to protect themselves. Trust me, the mortgage companies don't care why you can't pay or are late. If you don't have excellent credit and money in the bank, we sadly can't take chance renting to you.

Forcing me to take a payment agreement while not forcing the mortgage company to do so puts me in a tough spot.  We might move to 6 month leases so that we can move on from unsatisfactory renters that much sooner.

Comment: There was a recent scandal in the wine market. An enterprising fraudster poured $100/bottle wine into $1000/bottle bottles. The One Percenters buying up this wildly expensive stuff surely couldn't tell the difference between a great wine and a rarefied one. Indeed, the One Percenters were often too drunk to tell the difference between a great wine and plonk.

Consider Duchamp's urinal Fountain. It has been reproduced by artisans because the original, bought by Duchamp in a plumbing store, was lost soon after it was photographed by Alfred Stieglitz. Of course, the urinal was a practical joke, an attack on censorship. And the elevation of it to a rare commodity is itself a comment of the perversity of art collecting.

New art is corrupted by marketing theories. Damien Hirst's diamond encrusted skull is of course worth a lot of money: It's encrusted by diamonds. But what's its added value? Hirst lost much of his reputation by overproduction. Scarcity is a sacred factor in marketing.

Comment: Today, in Canada, tax exempt labour organizations, including unions, are not required to make public their financial affairs. This is in contrast to countries like France and America that have public union disclosure as a result of union leadership in seeking and supporting it. Numerous other nations such as Germany and Australia also have public union financial disclosure.

Labour organizations are exempt from taxation. Unionized Canadians who pay dues deduct those dues from their taxable income. Dues are almost always a “condition of employment” – employees who do not pay them can be fired from their jobs – a possibility sanctioned by labour codes. Strike pay is also not taxable income. Unions transfer dues to local, provincial and national umbrella labour organizations.
http://www.labourwatch.com/topics/disclosure

Comment: grammar: "move to WEAR the jobs are???? I purchased two houses out in rural Alaska and gave them to my children. Comment: As nice as this is for Tesla owners, it'll be interesting when EV's can recharge at any station. Imagine if we had gas stations (or even gas pumps) for Fords that were different than Toyotas and different from Dodge, etc.  You arrive in town low on fuel in your Honda only to find the town doesn't have a Honda refueling station. 

Once something akin to the Tesla Supercharger tech is universal, that'll make EV's more attractive. Right now, they are mostly for electric enthusiasts, hobbyists and for use as town/urban cars, where they shine. 

But Tesla and Chevy Bolt are getting close to being cross-country cars. Tesla is getting 170 miles range for a 30 minute recharge. Nobody else can match that. But until they approach the convenience of petroleum refueling, they will remain more of an urban phenomena for most folks.

Comment: I was in Amarillo for the first time a couple of years ago.  The day and night I had to spend in that hot, dreary town was the absolute low point of a otherwise great cross-continent drive.  The only redeeming feature I found was a dingy little Mexican restaurant where I had the very best guacamole I've ever eaten.

But, hey, Anchorage isn't such a hot town, either.  But after living here many years (as well as elsewhere in Alaska, including the Bush), I must say I've seen very little evidence of hate, including religiously-inspired hate.  I know quite a few Christian people who firmly believe that being gay is sinful.  But they also know they live in an open society that long ago chose tolerance over conformity. Comment: I'm inclined to agree. When I was a kid, we had only three TV channels, no internet, and our friends were real. Perhaps more important, what we saw was real, too. No carefully tailored online personas making us feel inadequate because our lives weren't as cool as theirs. No "likes" or other reactions to judge the worthiness of our thoughts, just face-to-face feedback. That can be really negative too, but at least you can escape it by going home.
Social media has its place -- it can be very useful, especially during times of emergency -- but using it to judge yourself is like comparing your life to a TV show. No one is as cool as the Fonz (no matter what their fb page says), so you're not a loser if you aren't either.

Comment: I started saving in 1997.

Good times.  There was the foreign cap in RRSPs (remember that?!?).  I was poring through some ancient statements wondering why on earth almost all my investments were in the TSX(E).

And... MERs on MF were super high.  2%?  Hah!  I remember bond MFs that charged more than that!  Some actively managed funds had MERs of 6%!!

It took literally decades for MF MERs to go down where they are now.  The only one I find even close to palatable is MAW104.  At least in the US exchanges Vanguard has MF equivalents for a lot of their ETFs at the exact same MERs.

So if you're wondering where WB is coming from, he's remembering the past few decades of investors getting ripped off big-time.

Comment: "Speed kills" is an overstated position. Yes, the faster you are going, the more likely an accident is to be fatal, and the less time you have to react to surprising things.

If you are driving in a way that is intended to force other drivers to change their behavior, you are not making the roads safer. You are doing the exact opposite of that.

Comment: Among the unmerited gifts of my life was Gregory's tutelage in Toronto.  His weaving the personal and social dimensions of faith together has had a lasting impact.

Once in conversation he offered an observation that has long helped me understand diverse pulls in the Church.  We were reading Johannes Baptist Metz, and he grounded that remarkable thinker's life's work in a personal question, offering a clarifying contrast.

Metz and Ratzinger were roughly the same age, raised in nearby Bavarian villages.  Their early social and religious experiences so similar, yet their life work so different.  The Holocaust set the question with which Metz has grappled ever since:  How was it possible that, in such devout Catholic setting, fervent, believing Catholics offered so little, if any, resistance to the rise of absolute evil in history?  Whereas Ratzinger felt deeply the loss of that peasant Catholicism in the face of modernity.

One of those concernss became Gregory's, too.

Comment: I am running for State House on the east side. I won't pretend to have every answer, but one thing I support is increased disclosure. Our legislators should have to spell out where their money is coming from on their websites and messages to constituents. Candidates should have similar rules. PACs should have to account for the source of their contributions. Making it easy for the public to know who is trying to sway our elected officials would not infringe on the rights of people to support candidates of their choosing, might cause a politician or two to consider where their money is coming from, and could allow for a simplification of the rules.
Meanwhile, I will not swim in the cesspool until it is cleaned up. If that sounds like the type of integrity Juneau could use at least one person of, please check out CommonSenseForAK.com and consider sharing with your East Anchorage friends.

Comment: You have not disputed what I said, but have merely expressed it in terms that may appear more palatable, but which in fact reflect a view which has long been rejected by the teaching of the Church - and thus is not at all palatable.  Forgiveness can be given to those who acknowledge their sin, repent of it, and resolve to avoid sin in future.  It cannot be given to those who do not acknowledge their sin, or do not repent of it, or do not resolve to avoid it in future.  Sure, life's situations can be difficult and complex, and yes pastors should engage with those in complex, sinful situations.  But until someone acknowledges their sin, repents of it, and resolves not to sin in future - the Church's norm for 2,000 years - the way to grant forgiveness has not been found.

You get a benefit for those taxes,  Income taxes fund the general costs of running the federal government: Defense, welfare, education, etc..  In fact, income taxes subsidize about half of Medicare's cost! So, don't whine about those taxes; you get a benefit!

I hate to break this to you, but your math is off. You say 54% of all personal income isn't subject to Payroll taxes, but's that's about 70% over what the the numbers show. 

$1.12 trillion divided by 0.153= $7,29 Trillion in income affected by payroll taxes*
In 2014, those taxes were $1.023 Trillion, with $6.7 Trillion affected by payroll taxes.*
Personal income (Total AGI) for 2014 was $9.77 Trillion in 2014 (the most recent year that IRS figures are available)

So, about $3 Trillion, or 31.5% wasn't subject to these taxes.
* Remember that SS tax stops; medicare tax keeps going. It's not all 15.3%

Comment: Running your engine just to warm up the interior is a waste of gas, but the engine should warm up a bit before driving off.  For the first minute or so after starting your car, the injectors put out a very rich charge of gas, which will wash the oil off the cylinder walls.  If you put the engine under load, the pressure of the rings against the cylinder wall opposite to the direction the connecting rod is pushing against the crankshaft can cause excessive wear.  It is best to get the oil flowing under full pressure and to let the fuel mixture lean out a bit before driving off.
That is a good time to scrape the windows.
There is a thing called "bore wash" which happens when you first start a cold engine.  All the oil washes off the cylinder walls and it takes a bit of time to replenish it and get your compression back.

Comment: The countdowns aren't intended for drivers, and they can't be "precise".  You might notice that sometimes the green lasts quite a bit longer than the countdown, especially when there's a transit vehicle loading nearside. Transit priority in particular throws it off.  You don't see it very often in Toronto (they're pretty open in that they don't think the drivers could handle obeying the signals instead of watching opposing traffic), but in areas where say NB traffic gets a protected left at start of green cycle, and SB gets protected left at the end, that the ped lights won't count down at the same time anyway. 

Streetcars, cyclists, and peds very much belong on Toronto's streets, which were laid out in the 19th century and never intended for large numbers of cars. They're not highways and never will be. Deal with it.  Cars are a low priority in big cities due to their inefficiency. They're necessary for some purposes but what Toronto has now is well beyond that.

Obamacare is actually about compulsory health insurance,  penalties of avoidance and stuff like free aspirin, birth control pills and dental plan for kids. 

It was sold as a magical way to simultaneously lower individual healthcare costs and increasing coverage.  

There's no doubt that there are things that it does well and can help those in need.  The mandatory coverage of those with pre-existing conditions will help those who might be wiped out financially because someone in their family has a catastrophic illness.

People like the free stuff but they don't like the increased premiums of their old plans.  There's anecdotal evidence that previous Obama voters opened envelopes of their insurance premiums and voted Trump.

Comment: Yes, but they adjust the numbers in the study for the number of adults.  So if in 1980 one parent was making $100,000 (in 2010 constant dollars) and one parent didn't file a tax return, they would be counted as making $50,000 per person, while their child making $50,000 in 2010 would also be counted as making $50,000 per person and be one of the 67% of children making as much or more as their parents.  So StatsCan has adjusted out the changes in family strucuture caused by declining real incomes and come up with statistics that they think show real incomes aren't declining.

Comment: I have attended the Prince Lot Hula Festival perhaps 20 times -- once when I was a tourist in the 1980s and then as a permanent resident since 1992.  The beautiful setting at Moanalua Gardens was a major part of the experience, including the dilapidated but iconic home of King Kamehameha V and his lo'i halo.

Over the years the festival (just like the Hokule'a homecoming) became increasingly politicized -- OHA had a booth with propaganda for the Akaka bill and tried to get people to sign up (kau inoa) for its wannabe tribe.  Opening ceremonies were marred with speeches (Brickwood Galuteria, Kimo Kahoano, Vicky Holt) rousing racial pride and tribalism.  Booths of profit-making vendors proliferated, unrelated to hula: clothing, jewelry, etc.

Hoopla and politicization are now out of control.  Hula will be a mere vestigial piece of the festival's anatomy (like an appendix, or tailbone).  Lota died long before the current Palace was built; no connection to Prince Lot.  Sad.  Skip it.

Comment: Aside from the silly statement at the beginning of this piece, it's a good one for a number of reasons. 

The silly statement?  Boomers are choosing to upgrade, "instead of making do with less." What "making do"?  Less cost on a monthly basis for the same living space as the big ol' house, Less property tax bite, less work and maintenance cost, and--less is more--a whole lot more retirement savings at the  end of the transaction.

The real message here, is: timing is everything.  (This couple made their move just before the foreign tax artificially changed the market.) Timing is VERY good for Marcon Developments, too: "...the beginning of a potential flood of downsizers that will become one of the biggest drivers of the condo market." Not just condos, either. Watch rancher/bungalow single-family homes take off.  "“This is the tip of the iceberg...could be a five- or 10-year run."  But...icebergs melt. 

The message for boomers?  Be the first on your block. Avoid the "glut" to come.

Comment: "..., because we’ve tried everything else."----Actually, we as a government have done everything to make this problem worse. We have increased the cost of living through higher excise tax, higher property taxes, taxes on everything from cigarette taxes (that do not stop smokers from kicking the habit) to taxes on soda cans to "taxes" on grocery bags to make life harder for everyone who is already struggling. Raise that property tax and you get higher cost of doing business for property owners which results in higher rents. Higher rents mean those who are struggling to pay their rent end up losing the place they call home. And for those who are struggling to find an affordable place to live, they now have higher rents to look forward to. Instead we build so-called "affordable" housing that do not even come close to solving the problem. Instead it enriches those who are building luxury condos. Why not offer tax incentives to home owners to offer up their homes for "affordable" housing?

Comment: Protest is certainly an essential element of a democratic society, but don't forget it is essentially the 'one night stand' of political activity.

Protests flag an issue(s); however, it is the laborious long term game of organizing that leads to change. Nor is it easy since it requires forging coalitions, sometimes with individuals and groups who do not see things exactly the way you do. Like a relationship, it requires commitment and accommodation, marked by disagreement if not argument, yet always coming back together on what is important. And it is better when you don't use phrases like "burn in hell" if you have any desire to reach out beyond the converted. While it is lots of fun riding a float or punching out a poignant tweet, don't expect the world to change. 

So lets hope a new generation gets a taste of the intoxicating power of political organization.

Comment: There is no inconsistency between assisted dying and palliative or hospice care, and those who, like Margaret Wente, think differently, have a thing or two to learn about palliative or hospice care. There is no panacea for care at the end of life, and for some people life in a hospice can be as soul denying as life on an ordinary hospital ward. If a person has a right to receive help in dying, then this should be provided, wherever the patient is suffering. Assisted dying is complementary, not contradictory, to palliative or hospice care, and, if the hospital is being funded on the taxpayer's dollar, they are entitled to receive help to die wherever they are. The dogmatic refusal to offer assisted dying is dogmatism pure and simple, and it is an unfair characterisation to speak of dogmatism only with respect to those who support assisted dying. Margaret Wente, if she thought a second about it, would be aware of this. This is an incredibly lop-sided op-ed, and rewriting is in order.

In the 70's and 80's, 5th Street was the place to really feel the 'texture' and uniqueness of Eugene.  There were Musicians like Fiddlers, flutes and many local guys and gals.  A Rooster roamed the area and he was a beauty.  People from the University, West side, South side..........just all over w/kids playing around the fountain.  Sawdust on the floors.  No commercialism.  Just totally downhome....w/o pretentiousness.  Now?  OMG  It sickens me to see such financial dedication towards a class of folks that are not a true representation of what Eugene was.  It's like a foreign planet compared to what used to be there and who enjoyed it........which was everyone.  l2g

Comment: I lived in China for more than twenty years and I know first-hand how wonderful the people of China are. They are caring, hospitable, and loyal.  I visited Chinese families in the countryside, where more than 70% of the population live. Now instead of having only one pair of winter boots for the entire family, everyone has their own pair. Thanks to the brilliance of Deng Xiao Ping who opened up the Middle Kingdom. I often walked through the streets of large cities and often those sitting on small stools on the pavement would invite me to sit and have tea with them.    Always eager to engage the Chinese, I found that after a few minutes, no matter who had invited me, I always felt as though we were old friends who hadn’t seen each other for a very long time. It was like that throughout my twenty years in the Middle Kingdom.    Canadians should be proud of lifting 500,000,000 by purchasing things made in China. Hundreds of thousands of tourists have visited China since I first went there

Comment: To answer the question in the title, it's a resounding NO. Mosquitoes are but just a tiny part of the reason for the endemic birds decline. It's also important to point out there are hundreds of species of mosquito, many predating man. As this article clearly states..habitat destruction, coupled with predators and climate change is the main reason we are in what scientists are calling "the extinction event period" in our current planets history. We have never seen such massive numbers of plant or animal extinction and habitat destruction since humans began forming civilizations. By all means control the mosquitoes, but without habitat there will be no place for the birds, or mosquitoes, or humans to live.

Comment: Our international legal obligations under the various conventions and treaties relating to refugees say otherwise and we have passed them into our domestic law under the 'Immigration and REFUGEE PROTECTION Act'.

In 1985 the SCOC in the case of Singh v. Minister of Employment and Immigration, [1985] 1 S.C.R. 177 determined that "everyone" within Canadian borders (including those without legal status)  have Charter rights and in particular refugee claimants rights under s. 7 that guarantee "fundamental justice (our version of due process).  As a result refugee claimants were given the opportunity to make their case before an independent tribunal.

The case law is clear that even passing " through eight other safe countries including the US before they arrive in Canada" does not disqualify a claim to Convention Refugee status although the Refugee Protection Division is entitled to look at the path to Canada in order to assess the well-foundedness of the fear of persecution being claimed.

Comment: My fixes for Toronto housing crisis:
1. Implement a 10% foreign buyer tax for property priced b/t $0-$1M; 15% tax for property priced above $1M.
2. Implement a 1.5% property tax surcharge for ALL HOMEOWNERS REGARDLESS of nationality on the portion over a certain threshold (say $850,000) and can be offset by income tax and ppl who have paid into CPP for more than 10 years. (with some short-term unemployment protection policy for ppl who lost their job)
3. 0% of the capital gain will be taxable for primary residence, 50% of the capital gain taxable for the 2nd property, and 100% of the capital gain taxable for the 3rd+ property at a much higher tax rate. (Rate to increase every 6 month to a certain threshold)
4. Implement a 3% annual rent increase control throughout the GTA regardless of built year or property type.

I think the market will have a 15-20% price correction if above measures are implemented

Comment: It is true that the U.S. spends nearly a third more on health care than the second-highest-spending developed country (Sweden), both in per capita dollars and as a percentage of GDP. But that reduction in spending can come with a price of its own: The most effective way to hold down health-care costs is to limit the availability of care. Some other developed countries ration care directly. Some spend less on facilities, technology, or physician incomes, leading to long waits for care. Such trade-offs are not inherently bad, and not all health care is of equal value, though that would seem to be a determination most appropriately made by patients rather than the government. But the fact remains that no health care system anywhere in the world provides everyone with unlimited care.

Comment: People earning more than $250,000 a year make up 2.7% of tax returns filed and pay 60% of federal tax revenues. Their average tax rate is 25.7%. People with incomes of less than $50,000 account for 62.3% of all individual returns filed, but they pay just 5.7% of total taxes. Their average tax rate 4.3%. In round numbers, the top 0.1% of families pay the equivalent of 39.2% of their income in taxes and the bottom 20% have negative tax rates. They get more money back from the government in refundable tax credits (not mentioning benefits) than they pay in taxes. That's from Pew Research.

http://www.pewresearch.org/fact-tank/2016/04/13/high-income-americans-pay-most-income-taxes-but-enough-to-be-fair/

Comment: Lots of people from Iran and China become Canadian citizens. Those countries might not recognize the Canadian citizenship granted to their own citizens, but that's hardly a problem for Canada.  I think the only situations that could be problematic arise where countries don't grant citizenship to children born in those countries to naturalized citizens of other countries who can't "pass on" their new nationality to their offspring, assuming of course that the parents' countries of origin won't confer status either. This would have the effect of creating stateless children, but that would be something thoughtful parents should consider. Nothing forces naturalized Canadian citizens to reside permanently in Canada. They won't lose their citizenship if they don't do so, however the nationality of any children they might have outside of Canada could in rare circumstances become trickier were Canada to align its dual citizenship regime with prevailing standards.

Comment: Dave writes: . “Most of the gains [in the value of exports] were due to stronger volumes, up 2.5 per cent, although they were also aided by a 1.3-per-cent rise in prices.” He is looking at the growth rate in the Laspeyres volume index for exports, and the corresponding Paasche price index. The chain Fisher volume estimates, which StatCan misleadingly calls chained 2007 dollars estimates, show a lower growth rate at 2.3%; the corresponding inflation rate based on a chain Fisher price index would be 1.5%, since the increase in the value of exports was 3.8%. One would really be an optimist to see a trend in this single month of solid export growth, with a trade war with the US likely to break out in the current quarter.

Comment: This is a good example of what the information revolution is supposed to be achieving, but it comes with the same perils that the article is talking about. I mean, we all research health information on the internet, and hopefully we are good at picking out reliable sources, but it's also true that there is a huge amount of misinformation available.

For instance, the anti-vaccination movement has been very active on the internet, and that is definitely a negative for public health.

More generally, it can be very hard to sort out genuine experts from dilettantes. This is ultimately why we still need governments and health authorities, and why it is so important to approach the internet with cautious skepticism even as we gain a lot of value from the information it makes available.

Comment: I think the point is, what is the goal of the program, who is the spending of public resources primarily designed to benefit ("society," or just the individual client), how do we quantify and measure its success in achieving its stated goals, and how do we weigh any unintended negative consequences?

"Having clients spend less time in jail", is not much of a goal, it only benefits the criminal so why spend limited public resources on it. You can do that simply by not arresting people. 

A better formulated goal would be "keeping people from reoffending, thus lowering crime rates, victimization of others, and incarceration costs (the true societal benefits worth spending limited public resources on). That the program would also turn former criminals into productive citizens is also a social good. That they "stay out of jail" is just a tertiary personal benefit society doesn't need to care about and shouldn't expend resources on. "Not commiting crimes" should be the default setting.

Comment: If a mega national corporation passes along the tax increase to consumers in general, then Oregonians would get a great deal. Let's say a company pays the 2.5% tax and passes the cost to consumers by increasing pricing. Oregonians are ~1/100th of the US population, so a national pricing scheme would increase prices by .025%, barely a blip to any Oregon consumer. That's a 100:1 return for Oregonians as a worst case scenario for a mega corp with national pricing schemes... a great deal!

I don't even know where to begin though if you are asking if companies use pricing elasticity as part of their pricing strategy. Of course they do. Apple iPhones are constantly priced throughout a year even though currency exchange rates and cost of good fluctuates throughout the year. If every change in price gets passed to the consumer there would be weekly price changes... there are not. 

So, what percent of sales in Oregon would be affected by this tax? That's something I would like to know.

Comment: I agree that there are many rural communities across Canada which a dentist's skills are needed and think one must be prepared to make certain sacrifices. However, I'm finding that for the younger dentists who are willing to relocate to a rural setting, the choice is not made in isolation and is much more complex than their own willingness to relocate upon graduation. A spouse or partner of a dentist may prefer to stay in the big cities where the couple is seeking to raise children and send them to the best public, private or religious schools. They may want to be close to their parents who may need support or have health concerns. We can't blame a dentist for considering family circumstances and placing their spouse and children's interests ahead of their own. If you met your spouse or partner during graduate school or undergraduate studies, chances are that you didn't consider his or her willingness to relocate away from family and friends.

Sina S. Amiri
www.dentalconsulting.ca

Comment: Shared narratives (myths) are necessary for social cohesion. But unquestioned myths are dangerous. Each generation inherits anew the same genetic heritage from our Stone Age ancestors and culturally transmitted myths from more recent generations. Some of these myths intensify the problematic aspects of our genetic heritage, notably our species' tendency to form antagonistic groups that sometimes dehumanize each other with horrific consequences.. We must carefully evaluate our myths and the emotions they arouse, especially now, when we have the means to wipe ourselves out.

Comment: It was a function of a few things.

A lot of the folks that played there were appealing to an audience that is old and getting older.  If i had to guess, I'd guess that that translated into diminishing ticket sales.

I live about 10 blocks from Hugh's and while i didn't go very often (sadly, these days that's true of all live music) I've noticed that the bigger names that used to feature frequently in their lineup seem to have tailed off.  That could easily be due to a lot of the older acts simply not being able to tour in Canada or choosing not to, or a symptom of bad times for that club, or bad times for live music pitched primarily at an increasingly old audience.

I've never heard anyone have much good to say about their food.  I can't speak to it myself, but the absence of good comments speaks loudly.

The business of music generally is not an easy one, and so far as I know that venue never made money and was financed by the owner from day one.  Sad but (I believe) true.

RIP.

Comment: I would recommend they hire someone to research officers' everyday work and develop a fitness test that reflects what would generally be required in the course of their duty.

The main issue with generalized "fitness" tests is they'll use place-holder activities to try to gauge ability without recognizing that performance on those tasks may be influenced by factors other than what they're claiming to measure. Ex: arm/ab strength being equal, push-ups will be harder for females due to the different center of gravity/weight distribution. For similar reasons, it's easier to hip-throw/trip/unbalance a male if you're doing grappling/take-down exercises. A test where people have to carry a heavy pack puts females at a disadvantage, even with strength and endurance being equal, if the packs were designed with a male form in mind and the weight distribution and shape of the pack was not adjusted as needed. Etc. Ideally, you would have sets of tasks people could select from to show aptitude.

Comment: Medical doctor--If you are a medical doctor, you understand what an audit is.  The NHS system audited their cancer survival rate and found it did not compare well with the rest of Europe.  I chose to report on the UK, because almost every supporter of single payer holds it out as the model for us to follow.  As for access to oncologists here is a line from a story in The Guardian which noted that 50% of cancer patients experienced long waits for care, "Lives are being put at risk because more and more cancer patients are not being treated quickly enough by the NHS as hospitals struggle to cope with demand, experts are warning."  If you prefer facts, versus propaganda, I suggest you read the news, not sources that feed confirmation biased pablum.  One of the reasons we pay higher costs for drugs is that EU countries do not allow companies to recoup R&D costs, passing them on to us.  It is easier to negotiate a lower price if you knock off one of the biggest costs up front.

Comment: I just listened to President Obama's farewell address, a truly inspiring speech. Our president calmed his adoring audience and called for "the peaceful transfer of power, just as GW Bush was gracious in his transfer of power", and just as Obama has facilitated the transfer of power to the next elected president. This is how the great democratic republic of the United States of America has always peacefully transferred power after an election by the people has chosen a new leader. We don't need to abandon our ideals, or the right to assert our ideals in opposition to a government that many think is opposed to basic citizen rights. Obama called for citizen activism and organization. We bid farewell to the best president for our troubled times since Franklin Delano Roosevelt.

Comment: Yonela,
The reasons for South Africa's subbornly high unemployment rate are well researched and well known.
The causes are many - poor educational outcomes, a mismatch between the skills and qualifications of those entering the labour market and the needs of the market, lack of business confidence which puts a damper on investment, labour policies which create a unionised elite earning above market wages and salaries, acting as a barrier to entry for new entrants etc etc.

To suggest that a single element - inflation targeting and restrtictive monetary policy - on its own is responsible for unemployment shows a complete lack of understanding of basic economics.

If you had built an Econometric model showing that inflation targeting is a significant factor in maitaining high levels of unemployment, perhaps we could take you seriously. 

You know that treasury, SARB and UCT all have sophisticated computerised Econometric models of th4e Economy?

lastly, correlation is not causation!

Comment: Rodney, the only steps they have taken to fix the deficit so far are to cut the budget a couple of years in a row, and cut the PFD in half.  The PFD cut hurts the poor much more than the middle or upper class.  Most of the people in those 138 rural communities are not middle or upper class, and therefore are feeling the pain of the steps taken to resolve the deficit much more than the average family on the road system.  This is indisputable, and the economist in this article states the same thing. And the cuts to the budget have affected a wide variety of state services, affecting those on the road system and the bush. 

As for the lifetime welfare comment, what would you suggest happen instead?  There aren't enough jobs in the bush.  Mandatory resettlement?  Who is paying for that?  Just how much is the state paying per year for this "lifetime welfare?"  I'm really asking because though I live in the bush I have no idea of the total figure.
